We’re making sure that the country is ready for Brexit on 31 October.

Today we’ve allocated an extra £9m for councils with major ports and local resilience forums across England.

Tariffs and trade deals - PM explains the economic benefits for the UK remaining in the EU:
PM: Looking at what experts say, the way evidence points & what makes our people better off, I believe we should remain in a reformed Europe
PM: So that’s what our membership of a reformed Europe offers: certainty.
PM: If we voted to leave many non-tariff barriers would still be in place, returning to the bad old days of endless forms & bureaucracy.
PM: Thirdly, the Single Market enables the EU to strike the most ambitious and comprehensive trade deals with the world.
PM: Secondly the Single Market doesn’t just eliminate tariffs, it eliminates other barriers to trade - what are known as non-tariff barriers
PM The first big advantage of the Single Market is that British businesses can sell to a continent of customers – 500m people – tariff-free.
PM: I know people want to understand more about Europe & the Single Market. Let me take you through 3 big advantages of the Single Market.
PM: There is going to be lots of debate about Europe over the coming months.  But the biggest issue on 23rd June is our economic future.

Why the UK will have the best of both worlds - stronger, safer & better off in a reformed EU
PM: I believe Britain will be stronger, safer and better off by remaining in a reformed European Union. #EUref
PM: This is a vital decision for the future of our country. And we should also be clear that it is a final decision. #EUref
PM: I am today commencing process to propose that British people decide our future in Europe through in-out referendum on Thursday 23 June.
PM: Our special status means we can have best of both worlds. We will be in the parts of Europe that work for us & out of parts that do not.
PM: The reforms we have secured will be legally binding in international law &  cannot be unpicked without the agreement of Britain.
PM: We have a new mechanism to finally enforce the principle that – as far as possible – powers should sit in Westminster, not in Brussels.
PM: We also established a new emergency brake so that EU migrants will have to wait four years until they have full access to our benefits.
PM: We have secured new powers against criminals from other countries including powers to stop them coming here in the first place.

The £96 billion Integrated Rail Plan is the biggest ever public investment in Britain’s rail network. 

We're #LevellingUp across the North and Midlands with faster, more frequent and more reliable journeys.

Contactless ticketing in the North, the East, the West Midlands and the South East will mean passengers can tap in and out with a debit or credit card, avoid ticket office queues and get the best price automatically. 
 
#LevellingUp

The Integrated Rail Plan will improve services to smaller cities and towns like Doncaster, Grantham, Huddersfield, Wakefield, and Leicester, which would have seen little improvement under previous plans.

#LevellingUp

The Integrated Rail Plan will see improvements made sooner, in more places and with less disruption to communities.

#LevellingUp

⚡ The Integrated Rail Plan will electrify and upgrade rail lines across the North:
 
🚄  the Midland Main Line from London to Leicester, Derby, Nottingham and Sheffield
 
🚄  the TransPennine Main Line between Manchester, Leeds and York
 
#LevellingUp

🚄 Northern Powerhouse Rail will connect Leeds and Manchester in 33 minutes.
 
🚄 HS2 East will speed up connections between Sheffield, Nottingham, Birmingham and London.
 
🚄 HS2 West will speed up connections between Manchester, Birmingham and London.
 
#LevellingUp

We can now take full advantage of the fantastic opportunities available to us as an independent trading nation, striking trade deals with other partners around the world.
This deal includes a commitment to maintaining high labour, environment and climate standards without giving the EU any say over our rules.
We will have control of our laws with no role for the European Court of Justice.
From January 1, the UK and EU will have a free trade agreement based on zero tariffs and zero quotas.

The PM spoke at #UNGA, calling on world leaders to deliver on aid promises #LeaveNoOneBehind
PM: If you’re committed to making progress towards these goals, the UK is on your side and we will work with you on our shared quest.
PM: We need a new global partnership, to ensure that all our policies really help to deliver progress for the poorest. #UNGA
PM: Achieving these Goals will take action, not words. As well as aid, we need investment, trade, growth and jobs. #GlobalGoals
PM: We need to put the poorest, weakest and most marginalised first – to #LeaveNoOneBehind
PM: This is a clarion call to the whole world. To eliminate, for the first time in human history, the scourge of extreme poverty
PM: Let’s inspire the world with what we want to achieve - reduce preventable deaths to zero and eradicate extreme poverty in a generation.
PM: We’ve been making these aid promises for years. Now, let us all deliver on them. The world is watching.
PM: Aid is not enough on its own. Of course not. But it is essential. And it works. #GlobalGoals
PM: This investment is helping the world’s poorest and most vulnerable people to build a better life. #UNGA
PM: We’ve kept our promises on aid. We haven’t just achieved the UN’s 0.7% target – we’ve enshrined it in law. #UNGA
PM: I’m proud to lead a country that has made a huge contribution towards this extraordinary progress. #GlobalGoals
PM: We celebrate the huge progress the world has made towards the MDGs and commit to go further with the new Sustainable Development Goals.

PM's @HouseofCommons statement about the #EUTurkey agreement on migration crisis in Europe:
PM: @EUCouncil I brought together EU leaders to ensure that we are all ready to provide as much support as possible to the Libyan government
PM: What is needed is a government in Libya with whom we can work. so we can co-operate with the Libyan coastguard, in Libyan waters.
PM: Britain has given more money to support Syrians fleeing the war, & the countries hosting them, than any other European country.
PM: Visa free access to Schengen countries only means the right to visit.  It does not mean a right to work. Does not mean a right to settle
PM: We are not giving visa-free access for Turks coming to the UK. We have made our own decision which is to maintain our own borders.
PM: RFA Mounts Bay & Border Force vessels are already patrolling the Aegean. Asylum experts and interpreters are already working in Greece.
PM: What we are doing is contributing our expertise and our skilled officials to help with the large-scale operation now under way.
PM: We have argued for a consistent & clear approach. Ending the conflict. Supporting the refugees in the region. Securing European borders.
PM: Because of our special status in the EU, Britain is not part of the Schengen open border arrangements & we’re not going to be joining.
PM: The single biggest cause has of course been the war in Syria. We have also seen rapid growth of criminal networks of people smugglers.
PM: I would like to make a Statement on last week’s @EUCouncil, which focused on the migration crisis affecting continental Europe.

PM @BorisJohnson met survivors at the UK Commemorative Ceremony for #HolocaustMemorialDay, including @SirBenHelfgott.
 
Sir Ben survived Theresienstadt and Buchenwald. He was reunited with his sister, Mala Tribich, in 1947.
 
He went on to become a British Olympic weightlifter.

“This must never, ever be allowed to happen again.”
 
PM @BorisJohnson met Mala Tribich MBE, who was liberated from Bergen-Belsen 75 years ago.

Hear her describe the day of liberation.

#QueensSpeech counter-terrorism strategy will be reviewed and a new Commission will work to stamp out extremist ideology in all its forms.
#QueensSpeech will provide our Service personnel with modern, flexible working opportunities.
A new independent advocate will act on behalf of bereaved families and support them at inquests #QueensSpeech
#QueensSpeech will make the private rental market more affordable and competitive and ban unfair fees for tenants.
#QueensSpeech will reform mental health legislation and ensure mental health is prioritised in the NHS.
#QueensSpeech will respond to the devastating life-long impact that domestic abuse has on children.
#QueensSpeech will increase the National Living Wage so that the lowest paid see their wages go up.
The #QueenSpeech will provide the powers to build and operate the next stage of the HS2 network between Birmingham and Crewe.
The #QueensSpeech will deliver a Trade Bill and a Customs Bill to enable the UK to conduct its own trade policy.
An Immigration Bill will establish new national immigration policies once we leave the EU #QueensSpeech
The #QueensSpeech Repeal Bill will provide a functioning statute book on the day we leave the European Union.

The @COP26 summit is our best chance to make the changes we need to safeguard the beauty and balance of the natural world, and to pass it to future generations.
 
The world must follow the UK's lead and commit to net zero emissions by the mid-century.

The UK continues to play its part in promoting the principles agreed 80 years ago, pursuing “the willing cooperation of free peoples in a world in which, relieved of the menace of aggression, all may enjoy economic and social security."

#UNGA

The first meeting of the UN General Assembly was held at Methodist Central Hall in Westminster in London in January 1946.

#UNGA

On New Year’s Day 1942, Churchill, Roosevelt and the leaders of the USSR and China signed what became known as the United Nations Declaration. 22 other nations signed the next day. This paved the way for the creation of the @UN in 1945.

In August 1941 Prime Minister Winston Churchill and President Roosevelt met on HMS Prince of Wales and set out a vision for a post-war world in the Atlantic Charter.

The Allied Powers signed up to these principles at another meeting in London.

The UK was instrumental in the creation of the @UN.

In the middle of the Second World War, the Allied Powers met in London and agreed the Declaration of St James's Palace, establishing the principles of a future peace.

These annual meetings are an opportunity to shape the international response to the big global issues of our time:

🔵 building back better from the pandemic
🔵 tackling climate change
🔵 creating a safer and more peaceful world

#UNGA

How the UK-wide NHS and Social Care Levy will help the NHS tackle the COVID backlogs and ensure dignity and security for everyone in adult social care.
 
#BuildBackBetter

Our health and social care reform is the right, reasonable and fair approach to enable our amazing NHS to come back strongly from the crisis.

Let’s tackle COVID backlogs, fund our nurses and make sure people get the care and treatment they need.

Our plan to ensure the NHS can build back better from the pandemic, reform adult social care and bring the health and social care systems closer together so they are fit for the future.

➡️

We’re taking necessary, responsible, and fair action to protect our NHS and ensure dignity and security in older age.

A UK-wide 1.25% NHS and Social Care Levy will raise £12 billion a year for frontline health and care services across the UK.

Address to the nation on the end of military operations in Afghanistan – Prime Minister @BorisJohnson
Thank you to everyone at the @FCDOgovuk Crisis Centre and around the world, working tirelessly to deliver the evacuation and resettlement of thousands of men, women and children from Afghanistan.

Two UK nationals and the child of a UK national are sadly among the casualties of yesterday’s attack at Kabul airport.

We are doing everything we can to get people to safety.
We’ve evacuated more than 12,000 people from Afghanistan and our teams are working hard to make sure they continue to be supported as they rebuild their lives here in the UK.

The barbaric terrorist attack in Kabul shows the importance of continuing Operation PITTING to the end.

The majority of those eligible have been evacuated and our teams are getting through to people as fast as they can. 

We will keep going until the last moment.
UK Armed Forces and officials are doing everything they can to help those in Afghanistan to whom we owe a debt of obligation.

British forces are working tirelessly to support the evacuation operation in Kabul. 

​​​​10,291 people have been evacuated from Afghanistan since 13 August, more than 5,500 of which are Afghans and their families.

PM today attended an event for the anniversary of the #MagnaCarta alongside the Queen and members of the Royal Family
.@nationaltrust volunteer Nigel Vines wins #PointsOfLight award for preparing Runnymede for #MagnaCarta celebration
PM: 800 yrs ago King John put his seal to #MagnaCarta, a document that would change the world.
PM: I'm here in Runnymede on the banks of the Thames. 800 years ago on this spot, King John sealed the #MagnaCarta.
Read PM's #MagnaCarta speech in full:
PM: So on this historic day, let’s pledge to keep those principles alight. Let’s keep #MagnaCarta alive.
PM: Liberty, justice, democracy, the rule of law – we hold these things dear and  they took shape right here by the Thames. #MagnaCarta
PM: #MagnaCarta is something every person in Britain should be proud of. Its copies may be faded, but its principles shine as brightly.
PM: The seeds sown here have grown throughout the world. In America; in India with Gandhi and South Africa with Nelson Mandela. #MagnaCarta
PM: The clauses inspiring those who fought in the English Civil War, giving fuel to the Chartists, succour to the Suffragettes. #MagnaCarta
PM: What is taken for granted here in Britain, is what others are crying out for, hoping for, praying for. #MagnaCarta
PM: The countries that have these things tend to be the long term successes. Those who don’t tend to be the long term failures. #MagnaCarta
PM: All over the world, people are still struggling to live by the rule of law and to see their governments subject to that law. #MagnaCarta
PM: What happened here eight centuries ago is as relevant today as it was then. And that relevance extends far beyond Britain. #MagnaCarta
PM: The limits of executive power, guaranteed access to justice, the rule of law, shouldn’t be imprisonment without trial. #MagnaCarta
PM: 800 years ago, on this day, King John put his seal to a document that would change the world. #MagnaCarta

Renee now lives in North London and has 5 grandchildren and speaks regularly in schools about her experiences during the Holocaust. #LightTheDarkness @HolocaustUK  6/6
After the war, Renee met Charles, a British Army Officer in Paris. Charles had been one of the officers who liberated Bergen-Belsen. They married in 1949 and had two children. 5/6

In March 1945, Renee and her mother were moved to Bergen-Belsen. They were liberated from the camp on 15th April 1945 by the British Army but Renee’s mother died in hospital 12 days after the liberation. 4/6
In 1944 Renee and her parents were taken by train to Auschwitz-Birkenau. On arrival she was separated from her father, who she never saw again. 3/6

PM: Democratic consent for the #EU in Britain is now wafer thin #EUspeech
5 principles for a new #EU: competitiveness, flexibility, power flowing back to member states, democratic accountability, fairness #EUspeech

On #HolocaustMemorialDay we remember the six million Jewish men, women and children murdered by the Nazis and their collaborators, all victims of Nazi persecution and all victims of subsequent genocides.
 
#LightTheDarkness @HMD_UK @HolocaustUK

Manfred survived and came to Britain in September 1946 to be reunited with his father. He learnt English and eventually graduated from London University with a degree in electronics.
 
He is married with four sons and several grandchildren. 
@HMD_UK @HolocaustUK 

7/7
The camp was abandoned just days before the war ended and Manfred and other prisoners were sent on a death march in appalling conditions. 6/7

As the Red Army approached Riga, Manfred and other prisoners were evacuated to Stutthof concentration camp in August 1944. He spent more than 8 months as a slave worker in Stutthof and its subcamps, including Stolp and Burggraben.  5/7

In August 1943, just three months before the ghetto was liquidated, Manfred was sent to a nearby labour camp where he was forced to work laying railway tracks. The prisoners in the camp were treated brutally and again subjected to frequent selections. 4/7

Manfred’s father was able to escape to Britain in August 1939, just days before the war began, but the rest of the family were unable to join him. In December 1941, Manfred, his mother and younger brother were deported by train from Germany to the Riga Ghetto. 3/7

Manfred was born on 21 April 1930 in Kassel, central Germany, into an Orthodox Jewish family.
 
He and his family suffered escalating persecution under the Nazi regime in the years before the Second World War. 2/7

To mark #HolocaustMemorialDay the Prime Minister met and heard the testimony of Manfred Goldberg BEM, who survived the horrors of the Holocaust.

Downing Street got into the Carnival spirit, inviting pupils from schools across London for music, art, food and a parade.

“We're committed to tackling plastic pollution and preserving the environment for future generations." – PM @theresa_may

PM: Today I have set out a clear vision for a stronger, fairer, Global Britain as we leave the European Union
12: We believe a phased process of implementation will be in the interests of Britain, the EU institutions and member states.
11: We will continue to work closely with our European allies in foreign and defence policy even as we leave the EU itself.
10. We will welcome agreement to continue to collaborate with our European partners on major science, research and technology initiatives.
9: It is time for Britain to get out into the world and rediscover its role as a great, global, trading nation.
8: We will pursue a bold and ambitious Free Trade Agreement with the European Union.
7: Not only will the government protect the rights of workers set out in European legislation, we will build on them.
6: We want to guarantee rights of EU citizens living in Britain & rights of British nationals in other member states, as early as we can.
5: Brexit must mean control of the number of people who come to Britain from Europe.
4: We will deliver a practical solution that allows the maintenance of the Common Travel Area with the Republic of Ireland.
3: A stronger Britain demands that we strengthen the precious union between the four nations of the United Kingdom.
2: Leaving the European Union will mean that our laws will be made in Westminster, Edinburgh, Cardiff and Belfast.
1: We will provide certainty wherever we can.

PM: We have enshrined #ArmedForcesCovenant in law to ensure our armed forces & their families receive the treatment & respect they deserve.

PM: British planes would make a real difference in Syria, just as they are already doing in Iraq.
PM: The House should be under no illusion: these terrorists are plotting to kill us, and to radicalise our children, right now.
PM: This evil death cult is neither a true representation of Islam nor a State.
PM: The threat from ISIL is very real. It is a fundamental threat to our security.
PM: I am absolutely clear that we must pursue a comprehensive strategy that also includes political, diplomatic and humanitarian action.

PM: We need the right people for our economy here and those who will help make our country, stronger, richer and more secure. #ukimmigration
PM: I want everyone to help by reporting suspected illegal immigrants to the UK via Crime Stoppers:
PM: we’ve got to be so much better at finding illegal immigrants and getting them out of our country. #ukimmigration
PM: we’re going to change the Citizenship test because there are no questions on British history.
PM: we are going to criminalise the breach of Forced Marriage prevention orders. #ukimmigration
PM: We will make migrants wait longer to show they are in a genuine relationship before they can get settlement. #ukimmigration
PM: We have been consulting on how to ensure family migrants are supported without becoming a burden on the taxpayer. #ukimmigration
PM: we need to makes sure that those who come through the family route are genuinely coming for family reasons. #ukimmigration
PM: Since May '10, UK Border Agency has revoked licenses of 97 education providers&suspended further 36.

PM: Excessive #immigration brings real pressures on communities up and down the country. #ukimmigration
PM: some #immigration is a good thing. It is right that we should attract the brightest and best. #ukimmigration
